PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Second Allotted Day)



    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [1st April, 2002],

    That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech

Column: 159

which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.". - [Mrs Lim Hwee Hua].

    Question again proposed.

    The Minister of State for Health and the Environment (Dr Balaji Sadasivan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I speak in support of the Motion of Thanks to the President.

    Singapore is at the crossroads in its history. The crisis we face is in part the result of forces that we have no control over. These forces were responsible for our past success. They are responsible for our present recession; and if managed correctly, they will bring us future prosperity.

    The first force is the force of the free market. In historical terms, the force of the free market is a relatively new force. When kings and queens controlled all the factors of production, there was no free market. Only when individuals had the right to private ownership of wealth, no matter how little or how much the wealth was, did the free market emerge as a force. Industrialisation and the division of labour greatly amplified its power.

    The last century has shown us that the free market is the most efficient way of organising the factors of production and producing wealth. The collapse of the Soviet Union is proof of the inefficiency of centrally controlled economies. The recent rapid prosperity of China is proof of the effectiveness of free market principles in generating wealth.

    When people of a common culture are divided by an accident of history, and one half follows a free market economy and the other half a centrally controlled economy, the free market economy has always performed better. West Germany was more prosperous than East Germany and South Korea is more prosperous than North Korea.

    Singapore by embracing the free market system and by having one of the most open economies in the world has become an affluent nation. However, the free market system is also responsible for our current recession. We can react in

Column: 160

two ways. The first approach is to try and ringfence our economy and preserve the status quo. Our economy will remain preserved, frozen in time, but the world will move on. Twenty years from now, foreigners will find us quaint. Just as we often remark when we are in less developed countries - this is how Singapore used to be in the 60s - they will say this is how their country used to be in the 90s.

    Or we take the second approach and look at the recession as an opportunity to allow the free market to reorganise our economy so that we will be more efficient and will enter a period of growth in the 21st century. We must not expect that when we come out of this recession, things will be like they used to be in the mid-90s. Our economy will change. Like the mature economies of the world, there will be a shift from a manufacturing-based economy to a more service-oriented economy. Like the mature economies, our dependence on construction must decrease.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the 1980s, I lived in the United States for five years in the State of Michigan, about a minute's drive from the World Headquarters of General Motors and about 15 minutes' drive from the World Headquarters of Ford Motors. The output of these two companies is greater than the GDP of Singapore. The 1980s were a period of anguish for many Americans. The Japanese economy appeared strong and many contemplated a future where Japan would be the premier country of the world. A Japanese corporation had purchased that icon of New York - the Rockefeller Center. Many thought the American auto industry would perish. Instead of protecting the auto industry, the US allowed market forces to restructure the industry. The auto industry was forced to make better cars more efficiently and by the 1990s, the American auto industry was again the strongest in the world.

    Today, it is the Japanese auto industry that is in trouble. Nissan required a

Column: 161

foreigner to restructure and save the company. Japan's reluctance to allow restructuring of its economy after its bubble economy burst has hindered its recovery. We must avoid the mistakes that Japan has made. To recover from this recession, we must further deregulate and allow market forces to make us more efficient.

    The second factor that we have no control over is globalisation. The search for profits has made globalisation a powerful force. It was the desire of Europeans to make huge profits from the spice trade that drove them to explore the world, discover America and circumnavigate the world. Since then, the world has become inter-linked and we cannot escape globalisation.

    Consider the fate of the African living in his village in the 17th century. European taste for sugar fuelled a triangular trade whereby trinkets from Europe were sold in Africa for African slaves who were then transported to the Caribbean to be worked to death to grow sugar, which would be sold in Europe for huge profits. Whether globalisation is morally good or bad is for philosophers to decide, but like the African in the 17th century, we cannot escape globalisation.

    What is new, however, is the degree to which the political and economic fates of countries are becoming inter-linked and the speed at which globalisation affects countries. Just imagine, Osama sitting in his office in Afghanistan reviewing the videos of Yishun MRT and the World Trade Center in New York. Because he chose to strike in New York, we were spared death and destruction. On September 11th, I was watching CNN. The first plane had hit the towers. The instant I saw the second plane hit the building, I knew it was a terrorist attack. So did millions of others across the world who viewed CNN. This is the speed at which information moves across the globe today.

    When Enron collapsed, dragging Arthur Andersen into the controversy, within days, our honest Singapore accountants working under the Arthur Andersen

Column: 162

umbrella had to consider merging with other firms.

    Globalisation brought the electronics industry to Singapore because it was efficient to locate the industry here. Globalisation is taking many of these factories to China and elsewhere because it is more efficient to be located there. We cannot fight globalisation. What we can do is to find a new niche in the global market where we are efficient and where we have an edge in competitiveness.

    The third force is the progress in the application of science. Discoveries in science by themselves may have no impact. But when they are applied, they can change the course of history. The Chinese discovered gunpowder but the application of gunpowder to cannons by the Ottomans brought the collapse of Constantinople and changed world history. Although the transistor was invented in the United States, it was Sony and other Japanese companies that were able to exploit its applications and have dominated consumer electronics ever since.

    The last two decades have seen a revolution in applied science due to the mass introduction of computers in the workplace and in the home. We must be thankful to the Economic Development Board for seeing the potential in the computer industry and bringing the computer industry to Singapore. But as the computer industry plateaus, we need to look for a new niche where advances in the application of science will fuel growth. The life sciences is an area that Singapore should consider.

    Although the Government cannot control the three forces I described, the Government must play an active role to complement and manage these forces for the benefit of Singapore. I believe there are three areas where the Government has a major role.

    The first area is with regard to the civil service and the statutory boards. Our civil servants and statutory board employees are men and women of integrity working diligently in the service of the nation. But

Column: 163

these institutions are shielded from the forces of the free market. Yet, they too must restructure and become more efficient or they may gradually become what Bertrand Russell called "a collection of officials, different for different purposes, drawing comfortable incomes", happy "so long as the status quo is preserved." It is Parliament's duty, those on the Frontbench and those on the Backbench, who must ensure that the civil service and statutory boards remain efficient and give the people the maximum at the minimum cost.

    The second area where the Government must act is to reduce the real difficulties faced by our citizens as a result of the recession and restructuring. We must do our best to help people through this period. However, we must be careful not to create a welfare state and avoid creating a dependency culture in our citizens. We should consider Abraham Lincoln's advice: "In all that people can individually do as well for themselves, government ought not to interfere."

    The third area where the Government should act is to see how we can utilise the economics of QWERTY, spelt Capital Q, W, E, R, T, Y, to help us. If you look at your keyboard, the keys at the upper left corner are Q, W, E, R, T, Y. When the typewriter was first invented, the machine would often jam when the operator typed too fast. So the keyboard was designed to be as inefficient as possible. Today keyboards do not jam, but we continue to use the same format for the keyboard, even though it is inefficient. Economists like Paul David call this, the law of positive returns or the economics of QWERTY after the keyboard.

    We can see examples of QWERTY all around. The IT industry began in the Silicon Valley through the foresight of Stanford University. Today, all those interested in the IT industry still continue to converge to the Silicon Valley, even though it is one of the most expensive places in the United States. Likewise, the entertainment industry

Column: 164

gravitates to Hollywood. Even Chinese films like Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Indian films like Lagaan look to Hollywood for approval at the Oscars as this translates into millions of dollars in the global film market. Patients from around the world travel to a small town in the middle of wheat fields in Minnesota to see the doctors of the Mayo Clinic. These are examples of QWERTY where an established practice gives a place a competitive advantage.

    About a month ago, I was introduced to a former Indian Minister who is now a top lawyer. He came to Singapore because an Indian company had a dispute with an Indian State government. The arbitration was being conducted in Singapore because it is becoming an established practice in many contracts in India to choose Singapore as a location for arbitration for disputes. I was greatly encouraged by this.

    Singapore has a brand name. If we can create a pattern where people within seven hours flying time come to Singapore for services in education, health, insurance, banking, law, research, entertainment, the arts, shopping and other services, these patterns will self-perpetuate and get fully established. Then, even if we are a high cost centre, the economics of QWERTY will work in our favour because we will have a competitive edge as established patterns tend to persist.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we are at the crossroads. The people of Singapore are pragmatic. They know there are no easy solutions to difficult problems. They do not pine for a lost past that will not come back. We, Singaporeans, are the children of tough and hardy immigrants. Survival is in our genes. If we, people and Parliament, see the future not as one full of problems but as one full of opportunities, opportunities for us to seize for our benefit, we can make Singapore one of the greatest cities of the 21st century.

    Mr R. Ravindran (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion.

Column: 165



    The President in his Address highlighted that as we upgrade the economy we must maintain and strengthen our social cohesion. Our income distribution is already stretched out. At the lower end of our society, those without skills have difficulty raising their incomes or even finding jobs.

    One of the tasks of the Economic Review Committee is to look at how to lower business costs. I think we pay greater attention to business costs because businessmen are a powerful group and they power the economy. I would urge the Government to go further and see whether the overall costs of goods and services can be relooked in Singapore. I would like to urge the Government to set up a committee to see how cost of living in Singapore can be reduced further.

    Sir, I meet and interact with many residents in Singapore. In my meetings with my constituents, it is clear that they are concerned with managing their lives on a day-to-day basis. For many low income families, the daily challenge is not only about the cost of living, but actually the cost of survival in Singapore. Many are struggling to upkeep themselves and their families. I am confident that there are many areas in the provision of Government goods and services where we can further lower our charges.

    Sir, there are many areas of expenditure where we can undertake a detailed audit of what is the real cost and what is being charged by the various Government departments. For example, I was pleasantly surprised when the Registry of Companies launched a new fees structure for registration of new companies from a minimum of $1,200 to $300 recently. Similarly, for a business registration, it has come down from $55 per year to $105 for three years. I am sure there are many other Government departments where there can be greater transparency on what is the real cost and what is being charged.

    Similarly, many statutory bodies must become more transparent on what they charge and what is their true cost. Can

Column: 166

some of the key goods and service providers, like the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Trade and Industry, including the Ministry of Information, Communications and the Arts, become more transparent on their costs and charges so that we can better understand whether the Government departments are recovering cost or whether they are profiteering marginally or grossly? This becomes even more necessary when the goods or services are provided by a monopoly. In fact, Sir, I take on and support the call by the Minister of State who spoke earlier that the Government must provide services and goods for maximum benefit at minimum cost. But somehow that is not the impression among many members of the public.

    I do hope that many statutory boards and Government autonomous bodies can adopt such accounting disclosures so that the true cost and revenue picture is well understood by the public. It will certainly help to restrain some of these organisations and moderate what they charge the public. I am convinced that some departments charge what the public can pay rather than what is cost recovery or even a reasonable return.

    Sir, recently, IRAS sounded out getting charitable organisations to disclose their income and expenditure statement of charitable organisations. It will also require disclosure about the top three salaries of their employees. I am very sure that it is a positive move as many donors would like to know how their donations are being used. If we can start setting benchmarks on how public donations are being used, I am sure that the Government can set even higher standards on the cost and revenue for each service and goods it provides to the public.

    Sir, there are many who are keen to know how much does Traffic Police charge for a police report as against the true cost of providing such a service. Some want to know how much is the cost of medicine to our hospitals as against what the particular hospital charges the public. I am confident that such public

Column: 167

scrutiny about our Government and quasi-Government bodies' income and expenditure will encourage them to be sensitive as to how they can charge the public. I am concerned as I am convinced that there are several Government departments that may be profiteering in the provision of some public services as against working on a cost recovery basis.

    I would similarly like to urge the NTUC, as the key provider of many services to the public, to similarly disclose to the public where it is possible on what is the cost of their services and goods they provide to the public and their union members. NTUC FairPrice, for example, can disclose to the public on how much they subsidise the public by disclosing the purchasing and operating costs and the selling price. Perhaps, such public disclosure would allow the public to better appreciate the subsidy or profit being made by our Government department or NTUC in the provision of goods and services. I am confident that this is also an area where CASE can play a useful role in looking into the areas highlighted and work towards reducing the prices of these goods and services.

    Sir, my hope is that the Government will not only lower costs for businesses but also for all Singaporeans. This will certainly go a long way in helping ordinary Singaporeans.

    Let me now move on to my second topic on relations with our neighbours. Sir, the President has spoken succinctly when he stated that our own region has fundamentally altered. Our two immediate neighbours are facing different challenges.

    Indonesia is still on the course of finding stability in many areas. We have seen the change of three Presidents in three years and the emergence of hitherto hidden but powerful forces. Their foreign and economic policies will be strongly dictated by a myriad of political parties and leaders and the need to soothe an increasingly stronger Muslim electorate. Compounding the problem is the emergence of the

Column: 168

media as a new power in Indonesia. The media is still groping on the markers between absolute free speech and responsible journalism. Important issues are commented and debated according to the political flavour of the day and the political affiliations of the media. Fortunately, our ties are deep and our friendship network is extensive.

    Sir, I am happy that we have helped and continue to help Indonesia recover economically. The participation of GIC in the purchase of assets by IBRA, the government-to-government loan assistance package, and recently the idea of including Bintan as an export corridor to the USA under the proposed US-Singapore FTA are laudable. The actions will help show that Singapore is indeed a friend in need.

    Sir, we must continue to remain engaged in a big way in Indonesia. It is a big and very large neighbour. Although some Singaporeans have turned negative about investing in Indonesia, we must never take our sights from Indonesia. Sir, regional autonomy offers tremendous business and other opportunities to Singapore businessmen. I have spoken to many Indonesians and many have highlighted of new investments from Europe, Japan and China into the provinces. I am not hearing much of substantial private Singapore investments in the provinces. I do hope that the Ministry of Trade and Industry will study ways to help Singapore businessmen explore and invest in Indonesia. My fear is that when real economic recovery returns to Indonesia, Singaporeans may be too late to join the bandwagon. Let us not ignore our own backyard where we have a distinct advantage and concentrate on faraway markets where the competition may be greater.

    In the case of Malaysia, it is the same old story. The season for Singapore bashing used to be spread out over a longer period of time. Recently, the time gap appears to be narrowing. The several by-elections there could be a factor. Well, the bad news is that analysts are predicting an early general election next year. The media in Malaysia has dutifully

Column: 169

done its part in portraying Singapore as the bad boy down south. Much as we ignore the Malaysian media, we must also understand that there is a whole new generation of Malaysians who get a regular dosage of anti-Singapore articles and news reports. Many have come to believe that many of these articles and reports are true.

    Sir, the latest issue on the land reclamation is a case in point. What started out as a comment by someone has now snowballed as a serious issue for them. Interestingly, no report has been disclosed by the state of Johor or the Federal government on what exactly is the damage done. The newspaper reports faithfully the comments by politicians, businessmen, academics, bureaucrats and even fishermen on the effects of reclamation in Singapore. What is clear from the press reports is that there is as yet no comprehensive report on the matter. The various reports are still being waited by the central government. Sir, their own government has stated that they are waiting for the reports to come from the various authorities. It may become embarrassing if later it transpires that (a) the reclamation does not infringe Malaysian territory (which we already know) and (b) that there is no substantial damage to Malaysia in any way. Having taken a stance that the reclamation is damaging even before the official reports have come in, clearly shows the mentality of our Malaysian neighbours - "Shoot first - we will find a reason later". Fortunately, neither our Government nor Singaporeans are rattled by this present rhetoric or past rhetoric.

    What is puzzling to me is what are the intellects in Malaysia thinking? Are they wondering why the Malaysian government has not done a proper study on the matter earlier? Were their government leaders, politicians, bureaucrats and diplomats so inept and inefficient that they were unaware of these reclamation works? Mind you, these reclamation works are well publicised in advance. In some cases, the reclamation project has been completed some years ago, eg, at Tuas. What then is the latest agenda of the

Column: 170

Malaysians? To tell us what we should do and not do within our territory? To rally their ground for their domestic politics? I really do not know and it may not be worth our time pondering over it.

    What is more puzzling is the new style of diplomacy that is emerging in Malaysia. Whenever there is a bilateral issue, the position there is to use the media. It is elementary diplomatic convention that relations between states are conducted through diplomatic channels. There are proper and a range of diplomatic tools to raise matters of concern between nations. While one can forgive small time politicians, bureaucrats, journalists and businessmen for not understanding the art and use of diplomacy, it puzzles me that the lack of understanding reaches the upper echelon of the Malaysian leadership. Perhaps, we can offer them some scholarships to undertake academic programmes in diplomacy and international law at some renowned universities.

    To compound the matter, the Malaysian press has been unhelpful in publishing the truth when explanations are given on why the reclamation will not impact or affect Malaysia. In fact, it gets no coverage at all. I recall the article put out by the Straits Times on 30th March which reads "Reclamation will not hit shipping lanes". It has yet to be reprinted or published in Malaysia. In fact, to show the attitude of the Malaysian press, let me just highlight one case. The New Straits Times just last week deliberately omitted a crucial paragraph that refuted the "underclass" claim in an article about Malays in Singapore. Well, that certainly helps us to know where the Malaysian media stands on matters concerning Singapore.

    Sir, in fact, if you want a joke, I picked up one last week. Malaysia's Berita Harian ran a comment by an unnamed retired navy rear admiral that our reclamation had paralysed a Malaysian navy centre in the Johor Straits. The article stated that the narrow gap between the two countries would cause sedimentation over the next few decades. This would allow Singapore's amphibious military vehicles

Column: 171

to cross into Malaysia with ease. When I first read the article, I thought, "What a brilliant planner we had in the SAF who was able to think decades ahead" because they alleged that in a few decades we will be able to cross the straits through this process of sedimentation. Then, I reflected, "But are they not making it easier for Malaysian amphibious vehicles to come to Singapore with ease?", in which case, our reclamation will end up helping the Malaysian Armed Forces to fix Singapore.

    Maybe this is a game of reverse psychology or even a case of poor logic or poor argument. I do not know. But what one can think for sure is that this "tak ada logic" barrage from across the Causeway will continue. What is clear is that there are many voices emanating from across the Causeway. By the time it reaches us, it becomes noise, a noise we have gotten used to just like aircraft noise generated from time to time over Singapore. They are a pain, but we have got used to it. Our destiny is here and we have to do business here. Let us continue to be friendly but firm, respect each other and not denigrate each other, let us discuss but not be talked to or talked down. Let us work for our mutual benefit and not for our mutual detriment.

    Sir, our Government has been doing right in treating our Malaysian neighbour fairly but firmly. We demand respect as a sovereign nation and we give them respect as a sovereign nation. We encourage investments and tourism in Malaysia. We have many relatives and friends on both sides of the border. We wish them well, for their prosperity augurs well for regional prosperity, as does ours for them.

    Sir, Singapore is a small nation. We have been successful in finding a place under the sun for our people. We must work as a team and look beyond these problems. We should leapfrog and establish our economic and political links everywhere. But we must remind ourselves that our home base is here and we

Column: 172

learn to live in this tough neighbourhood. We have done so as a nation for the past 37 years. I am confident that with a sound Government, united people and a strong SAF, we can meet these challenges.

    I support again the Motion.

    Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the Motion moved by Mrs Lim Hwee Hua in thanking the President for his Address at the Opening of this Tenth Parliament.

    The President's Address focuses on our need to be pragmatic in the light of a dramatically changed world and the challenges ahead of us. We are indeed facing unprecedented economic competition from all fronts, as we now emerge from last year's recession. This is placing us in an increasingly tight spot as our neighbours and many others, particularly China, eye for the same economic pie. The quality of Singapore's education system does provide niches for us to provide world-class education and research services. We must aim to be an innovation centre which produces recipe for success, new products and services, and best practices. (iii) Integrating our construction industry

    The construction industry has always been a "low productivity" industry. Despite all efforts by the Building and Construction Authority (BCA), productivity remains low. Why is construction productivity low in Singapore? Let me explain the phenomenon. Almost every building in Singapore is developed by different teams of developers, consultants and contractors. A building is a complex product which comprises the inputs of a few hundred trades such as concrete, steel, bricks, tiles, glass, electrical and mechanical products, and many others.

    In every building project, the developer will specify different design and building material requirements. As such, there is always a learning curve for the designers and contractors in every single project. This situation is further aggravated by

Column: 192

the lack of standardisation and modular coordination of building components. Columns, beams, doors, windows, tiles and fittings all come in different shapes and sizes, thus making it difficult to achieve high productivity in construction.

    While we encourage creative design, there is an urgent need to promote more standardisation and modular coordination in the construction industry. We must also integrate our design and construction teams through design and build. Developers must be encouraged to support standardisation and dry construction methods such as precast and off-site fabrication, without which construction productivity will always be low.

    Another contributing factor to the low construction productivity is the lack of mandate of the Building and Construction Authority. BCA does not control the provision of manpower and administer building regulations, which come under MOM. It does not implement standards and codes of practice, which is the responsibility of PSB. The Environment Ministry regulates environmental and public health matters on construction sites. With so many different agencies acting together with different agendas, how can building projects progress smoothly on site? We need to review and integrate all regulations affecting the construction industry and encourage more self-regulation. We also need to remake BCA.

Teamwork

(i) Friends to all countries

    Mr Speaker, Sir, no man is an island. Although Singapore is an island, we must work as a team with the international community. As a country, we should continue our foreign policy to be friends with as many countries as possible. We must be committed to ASEAN and be supportive of international organisations, in particular the United Nations. We must strengthen our friendships with other countries and forge economic partnerships where possible for mutual benefit. The pursuit of Free Trade Agreements will provide excellent opportunities for businesses to collaborate and provide

Column: 193

products and services to growing markets such as China, Korea and Indochina.

(ii) Building a Singapore Team

    Back home, we should encourage our people to work closely as a team to compete globally. We need to build a Singapore Team and brand our team. Both our Government-linked companies and local businesses must work as partners to provide global products and services. We should work as a team to develop more world-class companies. Thus, the Government must provide more support to nurture local businesses to be global players. The public sector and GLCs should also make concrete efforts to support local SMEs and provide opportunities for them to grow.

    GLCs should reduce its local market share and give local businesses opportunity to provide their services and gain experience. We need the inertia from the private sector to drive our products and services overseas. We should also reduce the stake of Government in GLCs and provide opportunities for private entrepreneurs to build niche businesses. In addition, GLCs can support local businesses when venturing overseas.

(iii) Teamwork in Government Ministries and Agencies

    To provide quality services for both our people and businesses, we need teamwork from all Government Ministries and agencies. Staff from the public sector must understand the macro perspective of policies and procedures. They must exercise more flexibility to safeguard the interests of our people and business. Top civil servants and Government agencies' chiefs must adopt both horizontal and vertical coordination and teamwork. Physical and mental barriers across Ministries and Government agencies must be removed to facilitate workflows and better delivery of services.

    Furthermore, top management in the public sector must adopt a more hands-on approach in formulating policies and procedures. While we do not encourage micro-management, top management

Column: 194

must constantly be in touch with their ground staff and customers to continually upgrade their operations. A hands-on approach will definitely provide more support and impetus in delivery of world-class services.

Quality

(i) Developing a quality culture and workforce

    To achieve sustainable competitive advantage, we need to focus on the quality of our products and services. We must inculcate a quality culture in our workforce, like the Japanese. Workers must understand and be convinced that quality will ensure the survival of their companies and jobs. Although PSB has been spearheading the quality drive through the ISO 9000 and Singapore Quality Award schemes, not many local firms have achieved world-class quality.

    In particular, the retail and construction sectors suffer from the image of poor quality of services. We need to address the issue of quality of services in our retail industry. Efforts by the Government to upgrade the retail industry will not succeed if there is no business for retailers. The constant push by PSB to upgrade retail businesses may suffer backlash, resulting in higher business costs and business failures. Instead, we should focus on how to bring business to businesses. This is especially so in Singapore where we have an oversupply of retail outlets. When there is business, businesses will be motivated to further improve their operations.

    As for the construction industry, our open tendering system has severe setbacks in ensuring quality of construction. The competitive nature and low profit margin in construction do not provide much room for contractors to focus on quality. Many developers, including the public sector, are reluctant to pay a premium for quality work. Furthermore, there is inadequate independent quality assessment and easily accessible information on the quality performance of developers, designers and contractors. The Building and Construction Authority

Column: 195

should develop a web-based database on the performance of developers, designers and contractors. We must also review the quality incentives for the construction industry.

(ii) Developing a Quality Tourism Hub

    Singapore aspires to be a tourism hub. Each year, we attract about 7 million tourists to Singapore. If each tourist spends $200 in our retail outlets, we should have a billion-dollar retail industry. Is this the case in Singapore? We may need to check whether the GST rebate by tourists indicates the size of tourist dollars spent in Singapore. With so many countries competing for tourists, Singapore must establish our niches to attract tourists from all countries. Presently, our tourist attractions, such as Sentosa, Zoo, Bird Park and Botanic Garden are facing an uphill task to attract tourists. We need new tourist attractions and more aggressive marketing of our attractions. We have to market Singapore as a world-class city worthwhile visiting.

    The low crime rate and safe environment, coupled with our beautiful garden city, provide excellent niches for Singapore to be a tourist attraction. We should capitalise on this to organise or bid for more world leaders meetings, international conferences, trade exhibitions, forums and gatherings. We can be the "World Business Centre" where political, economic and social discussions take place. In addition, we should develop Singapore into a food paradise with a wide range of international and local cuisines, ranging from hawker centres to fine dining outlets. The East Coast Park can be converted into a "World Food Paradise or Esplanade" where the best food in Singapore can be housed together.

    Sir, we need to remake our Singapore Tourism Board (STB). Tourism can be a key driver of our service industry. It provides many jobs which our older workers can do, such as tour guides, housekeepers, drivers, customer relations officers, chefs, and so on. We must be

Column: 196

more proactive to attract more tourists. STB must reach out and encourage tourists to spend money in Singapore, instead of using Singapore as a transit centre. We need to revitalise the Singapore Tourism Board, Orchard Road, and our tourist attractions. I am sure Singapore can easily accommodate 10 to 12 million tourists a year.

(iii) Quality of life.

    Sad to say, Singapore has no quality of life index or measure to monitor our efforts in improving the quality of life of Singaporeans. Although many Ministries have put forward statements of vision and mission, no quality of life measures were stated to determine whether we have achieved our vision and mission. Many countries have some measures or benchmarks of quality of life. To be a world-class city, we need to establish our own set of quality of life indicators. This is to ensure that we utilise our resources properly to improve the lives of Singaporeans.

    Sir, let me cite one example to illustrate the importance of having quality of life indicators to measure the performance of the public sector. Every year, we spend billions of dollars to develop and maintain parks in Singapore. However, not many Singaporeans visit these parks, especially the national parks. The lack of accessibility and supporting infrastructure has deterred many from visiting our parks. Not many activities or programmes are organised to attract Singaporeans to the parks.

    Furthermore, inadequate or paid car parking has always deterred people from going to the parks. Sir, I am surprised to learn that you need to pay $1 for taking a walk at the Sungei Buloh nature trail. How many Singaporeans are willing to pay $1 per walk? The "pay as you use" principle or policy must be reviewed to facilitate better usage of our parks and nature reserves. The Government must invest in the well-being of our people. The use of parks has proved to be good relaxation places for many people in other countries. There is no point spending so much on parks when the utility is so low. Our National Parks Board should be more proactive to bring life into our parks.

Column: 197



    To have a good quality of life, Singaporeans must learn how to work hard, stay healthy and enjoy life. Maybe, the Ministry of Information, Communications and the Arts should set up a Department of Enjoyment to help Singaporeans enjoy life. To be a world-class city, we need to have a measure of our quality of life.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am confident that Singaporeans will stay united and integrated. We will work as a team and provide world-class products and services. Together, we can make Singapore a world-class city.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion of thanks for the President's Address.

I would like to elaborate on three of these stress points and the need to provide relief for them so that they do not manifest themselves into more serious ailments.

    The first stress point relates to the people-Government relationship. There is a danger of an increasing chasm between the Government and its people which the President in his Address identifies broadly as the need for political renewal. It is undeniable that the political leadership has over the last 36-37 years done much good for Singapore. Most Singaporeans have a tacit understanding that Government policies have good intentions. It is just like the boy in Jack Neo's show "I Not Stupid" who said, "My mother is like the Government. Everything she does is - for our own good."

    Singapore's past successes have hinged on meritocracy and pragmatism. Hitherto, economic issues drive Singapore and rightly so in view of her limited resources, smallness and thus vulnerability. Feedback from constituents suggests that Singaporeans, especially the younger

Column: 198

generation, increasingly want to have a say in Government policies. While there has been more consultation and dialogue with the citizenry over the last few years, there is still a feeling that there is some way to go with the new consultative approach. Otherwise, the citizens will view the Government feedback mechanism - however elaborate or sophisticated - as a black hole, where under the force of gravity, no light emerges. As a constituent once cynically remarked to me "Where is the Government's feedback to my feedback?" After public consultation and debate, the Government should take pains to indicate the changes or refinements made to its policies arising from feedback as well as the reasons for rejecting other proposals.

    It must show that it will not hesitate to take concrete action and change its policies, where it benefits the majority of Singaporeans, even if it involves an about change or about face of an existing policy, such as in the Chek Jawa case. Otherwise, many Singaporeans would continue to feel that dialogue and debate are mere tokenism. By way of anecdotal evidence of

Column: 199

this sentiment, even the CEO of an established private company in Singapore who has taken part in many feedback sessions and sits on the Board of a GLC, told me recently that he himself is still very sceptical about the Government listening to concerns about the impact of its policies. So this is not just the sentiment of the MP for Sembawang GRC's daughter or young friends. So what more the average man-in-the-street, most of whom have chosen to be the silent majority!

To ensure that policies remain relevant and enhance rather than impede stakeholders' welfare, as the MP for Sembawang GRC has so robustly argued, it is important to remind civil servants who are the face of the Government and facilitators of Government policies, that they must show compassion, be less rule-book bound and listen with a heart, not just with the mind. In other words, be customer-centric, in form and substance. Otherwise, they will not live up to their title of "civil servant" and will be considered neither civil nor servant.

My recent experience as a private sector representative on the JTC's Customer Services Panel and URA Concept Plan Review Committee 2001 have been positive. In these instances, the Government organisations concerned have been responsive to feedback and have made the effort to take into account some of the suggestions as well as explain why others cannot be implemented. However, more can be done, so that our civil service would be known not only for its incorruptibility and efficiency but also for being in-tune with the people and the needs of the time.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, my second point relates to the need for us to manage the

Column: 200

imbalances arising from an inevitable widening income divide among the have-nots, the haves, and the have-lots, as a result of the inexorable forces of globalisation and IT.

    As we promote entrepreneurship and risk-taking, there will be fabulous successes but there will also be spectacular losses. To quote the New York Times journalist, Thomas Friedman, there is no longer a First World, a Second World or a Third World. Firstly, as income disparity becomes more pronounced and as job insecurity increases, our meritocratic system upon which much of Singapore's success lies must be peppered with a lot more compassion in its execution. While we celebrate the icons, the phoenixes, and the heroes of capitalism, we must never forget those who are left behind. A group is only as strong as its weakest member. In a 4 x 100 metre relay, a slow start by one runner, or a poor baton change by another, can cost the team a medal. We thus need to temper capitalism with compassion.

    Existing financial assistance schemes for the low income groups, the handicapped, the sick and at risk families administered by grassroots organisations, the CDCs and MCDS are to be applauded. Column: 201



    Feedback from some constituents is that the financial assistance rendered by the Government, while very much appreciated, is paltry at times and, in some instances, not commensurate with the stringent requirements imposed. Far from it, as I wholeheartedly support the promotion of self-help and the dignity of work, a point which the Minister of State for Manpower expounded so poetically yesterday.

    Let me cite an example. A resident in my constituency is an able-bodied odd job labourer. He is now unable to work as his wife is suffering from terminal liver cancer and he is looking after her and their two sons who are still schooling. As a volunteer worker recently remarked to me, "While it is right for the Government to promote self-reliance and the dignity of work to avoid the development of a crutch mentality, our means test must also not be so stringent that it is considered a mean test rather than a means test."

Allowing the brightest and the best to excel economically and the worst off to receive assistance will address the top and the lowest echelons of society. Column: 202

is to redouble our emphasis on education and training.     Mr Speaker, Sir, my third point is the need to manage ethnic polarisation in our society. This has always been a thorny

Column: 203

issue in domestic politics. One needs to bear in mind the context of race relations. The reality, whether we like it or not, is this: Singapore as a Chinese dominated society in a region comprising ethnic majorities. There are sometimes unspoken concerns that centre on where the stronger pull lies: (1) blood and kin and, increasingly, one's religious faith; or (2) loyalty to one's country.

    Sometimes, the problems are compounded by the socio-economic distinctions that exist among ethnic groups that have led to the, at one time, controversial formation of self-help groups like MENDAKI and SINDA. We need only to recall the major strides we have made. Elsewhere, racial tensions are often resolved violently - in India, the Balkan republics and in Africa. We are blessed to have an enlightened leadership that lived through tumultuous times in our history and appreciates from bitter experience how racial fault lines can ruin everything we have so painfully built up over the years.

The issue continues to haunt us after decades and continues to morph into new forms, whether it be madrasahs, tudung or something else. If we are not vigilant, the cracks will widen and undo everything. We must never allow that to

Column: 204

happen. This is more important than ever before not merely due to recent events but also due to the international talents we are trying to attract who are also from diverse ethnic groups and religious persuasions. Indeed, the concept of a multi-racial, multi-religious society may be foreign to our foreign talent, some of whom hail from ethnically more homogeneous societies. The issue of social integration and cohesion could take on an added dimension when the number of foreign talent in Singapore becomes significant. Hence, we must never let up on efforts to foster greater cohesion among the people.

    Sir, as a nation, we should re-affirm multi-racialism as a creed, as the only way forward. Efforts continue to be made in schools with the formation of the IRCCs and Harmony Circles at the community level. I applaud such moves.

The nation had already grieved for the victims and their families. The service was a grim reminder to the rest of us who are not victims or their family members. Column: 205

While some may be sceptical, many others I know, including middle income and successful professionals who have watched these parades "live", often speak of how proud they felt to be Singaporeans.     Sir, I have dwelt at some length on these three critical stress points, which could become more acute over the next few years as Singapore operates in a changed environment. These stress points, in addition to others, need to be managed so that they do not fester and affect our political, economic and social health. A little stress helps to keep the adrenaline pumping and thus sharpen our competitive edge, but too much stress could pose serious health hazards for Singapore.

    Sir, the world today is not the same as before. It has become competitive, complicated and even controversial. We need to adjust and innovate in order to

Column: 206

progress and advance. While we want to narrow the divide between the poor and the rich, we also want Singaporeans to be self-reliant and independent. While we want to be more open and allow opportunities for dialogue and consultation, we also want to ensure constructive and useful debates. While we want to provide more space for individual communities to grow, we also want to build consensus and common grounds. These are some of the S21 dilemmas which continue to challenge each generation afresh.
